References Created by Branching Views

When a branching view is created, each folder or item automatically shared from the parent view to the child view acquires an additional reference. In the reference hierarchy, the new reference displays as a child of the original reference.

The Current icon indicates the reference that represents the currently selected folder or item. Otherwise, it contains the same information, regardless of the view in which you selected the folder or item. The references for child views are indented beneath the reference for their parent.

References in boldface type indicate which revisions of the folder or item are the descendants of the folder or item with the Current icon. The current folder is considered a descendant of itself, so it is always shown in boldface type. However, once the folder or item in the other view changes, it no longer appears in the history of the current folder.

When you look at the history of a folder or item, you see its ancestors, not its descendants. However, if you change the tip revision in one location and that revision is an ancestor of a tip revision in another location, you might want to apply a change to the tip revision in the other location (the first object’s descendant) as well. The way to tell if a revision has descendants is to look at its references.

You should check for descendants before (and perhaps after) you create a new revision of a folder or item. Before a change becomes a new revision in StarTeam, you can see its descendants. Afterwards, you may see what other references have the same revision number as the newly changed folder or item. If they also have the new revision number, then they also already have the new change. For example, the file may be floating in other views.
